additionalTextInformation.text:
In addition to the example in Kassel nine further versions exist of this  double portrait type bearing the date 1543. They vary only slightly in the background colour. [1] The standardisation and the number created within one year suggest that they satisfied a large order, which served to disseminate an 'image', which had found its definitive expression for both reformers.[2]
[1]Cat. Kassel 1997, 86. Examples are the version in Schloss Gottorf (on loan from a private collection, Exhib. Cat. Bremen 2009, Nos. 10/11, fig.) and that sold in an auction in London (Sotheby's), 10 July 2008, No. 104.
[2] See Warnke 1984, 61 f.; Hinz 1994, 175. Kurt Löcher presumed that a supply was painting in advance and that the date could refer to the year the firat version was created and not the later repetitions, see Löcher, Cat. Nuremberg 1995, 370. 
[Gerrit Walczak, Exhib. Cat. Gotha, Kassel 2015, 156]

pageContext.description:
The reformer also wears a gown. His beret extents further out at the sides, the outline of his shoulder is steeper and more sweeping on the left, while his chin is framed on the right by a high collar. There is a succinctly implied book between his hands on the right. Judging by the size it is probably not a Bible, which would have indicated the importance of the Holy Scripture within the Lutheran Faith. 

[Cat. Kassel 1997, 85]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 20.6/20.8 (left/right) x 15.1/15.2 (top/bottom) x 0.7 cm (slightly trimmed along the left edge)
[Cat. Kassel 1997, 82]
pageContext.markings:
Reverse of the panel:
- top centre:
two labels with the numbers 'N36' and '231' in brown ink  
- beneath:
in red pen '25'
- another label with a distich, also in brown ink: 
'En Cranachius integrum vitae hocce loque[nte]
Vultu Lutherum peniculo exhibuit
G.C. Beir(eis)'
(translation: 'low and behold, with his brush Cranach has depicted Luther with a meaningful expression, befitting his decorum') 
- directly beneath:
label with the number '130'  
[Cat. Kassel 1997, 82]
[Exhib. Cat. Bremen 2009, no. 12]

metadata.title: Portrait of Martin Luther

pageContext.provenance:
- the portrait was [together with its pendant, cda 2013] the property of the doctor, scholar and collector Gottfried Christoph Beireis (b. 1730 Mühlhausen/Thüringen, d. 1809 Helmstedt). He is the author of the distich on the reverse of the panel.
- acquired in 1891 from the art dealer Klingelhöfer, Marburg

[Cat. Kassel 1997, 82]
